awd_titl_txt: Response of tremor and slow slip to tidal stress: Constraints on fault friction and weakening
awd_abstract_narration:
In the past 10 years seismologists have discovered a new type of fault behavior - epitomized by slow slip earthquakes on plate boundaries, in which slip on a fault occurs over a much greater area for a much longer time than for regular earthquakes. These events cannot be felt, but are often detectable with GPS. Here the PI studies the effects of small, but relatively well-known, stress changes on slow slip earthquakes. The gravitational attraction of the Sun and Moon on the Earth stress and slightly deform the Earth and also raise water tides that flow and add to the changing stress. These small stress changes affect deep fault zones and modulate slow slip and tremor, which is recently-discovered weak seismic radiation associated with slow slip. The tidal stresses can be calculated, so one can assess the effect of small known stress changes on the generation of tremor, which is a marker for slow slip.  The results bear on how slow slip is enhanced and suppressed by tidal stressing, on levels of rock friction deep in subduction zones, and on how the fault interface weakens as slip accumulates during large slow slip earthquakes. This work provides the first such estimate of in-situ intrinsic friction deep in a plate boundary. Constraining the friction in deep subduction zones to a very low level, as preliminary results indicate, is potentially tranformative, and has implications for aspects of subduction zone science well beyond seismology, including petrology, slab stresses, and geodynamics.

Episodic Tremor and Slip (ETS) is a recently-discovered phenomenon in which weak seismic signals called tremor accompany slowly-propagating shear slip on a plate boundary interface in slow earthquakes, often with durations of several weeks. Deep on the Cascadia subduction zone under northern Washington, large M6.6 to 6.8 ETS events occur with unusual regularity for a seismic phenomenon, roughly every 14 months. The proposed approach utilizes the well-calibrated tidal stresses to probe the response of the region accommodating episodic slow deformation in the deep subduction zone. Analysis of tidal stresses at the time and location of 33,000 tremors from 6 ETS events reveals the strong influence of tidal stress, and particularly, that tremor sensitivity to tidal stress evolves, increasing over several days as slow slip accumulates at a given location. This increase in sensitivity implies progressive weakening of the fault. This work will extend the study of the influence of tidal stressing to 1) tremor that occurs between the major ETS events, 2) large ETS events all along Cascadia, and 3) ETS events in Japan. The PI will also determine preferred poroelastic models that provide the best correlation between tremor and tidal stresses. The goal is to better constrain friction and fault weakening and restrengthening on the plate boundary during the ETS cycle. The preliminary research has yielded the first clear finding of evolving tremor sensitivity to tidal stress over days of ETS slip at a given spot, likely due to progressive fault weakening.  These results constrain the timing and degree of fault weakening during ETS, while the proposed work will address the timing of restrengthening during the 14-month intervals between ETSs, as well as the relative behavior of tremor tidal sensitivity in different geologic and tectonic settings along the Cascadia subduction zone, and along the Nankai-Kii subduction zone. Additionally, the preliminary research has yielded the first in-situ estimate of intrinsic friction on the deep subduction interface, while the proposed work will deliver similar results for a wider sampling of locations and portions of the ETS seismic cycle. This approach has shown the potential to constrain key properties and processes in the deep subduction environment: intrinsic friction, fault weakening, and subsequent restrengthening. Furthermore, the possible effects of slow-slip-generated stress on the adjacent hazardous locked portions of subduction zones mandate better understanding of slow slip phenomena. For example, it appears that the recent devastating 2011 Tohoku earthquake was preceded by slow slip.

por.por_cntn:
Broadly stated, the general goals of this research were to characterize the behavior and mechanics of slow slip regions that are located downdip of locked subduction zone megathrusts. This is of interest because these slow slip regions gradually transfer stress to the locked seismogenic zone and thereby play a key role in loading the locked zone. More specifically, we aimed to study slow slip using seismic tremor occurring mainly in the Cascadia subduction zone, but also in the Nankai, Japan subduction zone. Tremor and slow slip occur together and propagate alomng strike through portions of the Cascadia and Nankai subduction zones, marking the occurrence of large but very slow earthquakes. This phenomenon occurs repeated and rather regularly and is termed Episodic Tremor and Slip (ETS).

One particular approach that we utilized involves analyzing how tremor is triggered by tidal or other stress changes. These stress changes can serve as calibrated probes of the stress state of the tremorgenic portion of the slow slip zone. Other approaches that we pursued included analyzing large slow slip events using GPS data, with a focus on spatial and temporal comparisons between tremor and slow slip.

Data analysis was performed using tremor and low frequency earthquake (LFE) catalogs, tidal stresses, GPS data, and earthquake catalogs. We made comparisons of stress characteristics with tremor occurrence. We estimated the distribution of slip from GPS data. In addition, we analyzed temporal relationships between seismicity in the subducting slab and about 50 ETSs beneath the Kii Peninsula on the Nankai subduction zone.

The research objectives were to determine in detail:

1 - the relationship between tidal stress and tremor or LFEs (Houston, 2015; Sweet et al., 2019)

2 - the spatial distribution of slow slip in large ETSs and relation to tremor from GPS (Hall et al., 2018)

3 - the spatiotemporal relationships between propagating slow slip and tremor (Hall et al., 2019) 

4 - the characteristics of deep in-slab seismicity that may be affected by tremor and slow slip earthquakes in the Kii Peninsula portion of the Nankai subduction zone Japan (Kita et al, 2021).

Significant results from the research that was supported by this grant (EAR 1447005/1911629) include the following:

  • The sensitivity of tremor to tidal stress rises during large slow slip events (ETSs) in Cascadia, and grows for several days as slip on the fault accumulates.
  • The functional form of the relationship between tidal stress and tremor was determined, and will provide constraints on models of the slow slip process.
  • The relationship between tidal stress and tremor allowed me to calculate a coefficient of intrinsic friction for the deep fault, and this showed that the deep fault material is intrinsically very weak.
  • Absolute locations of these LFE families place them very near and probably on the inferred Juan de Fuca-North America plate interface.
  • The LFE families respond to tidal stress in a manner similar to tremor, but with these data we can now detect that the sensitivity to tidal stress increases with downdip position.
  • Over several days of slow slip at an LFE patch during large ETSs, LFEs become increasingly correlated with positive tidal stressing.
  • Observed LFE behavior provides evidence for stress transfer and increased frictional strength with position updip through the tremor zone.
  • We present slip distributions for a catalog of six major ETS events from 2007 to 2016.
  • Slow slip is mostly co-located with tremor, but also extends about 15 km updip of tremor beneath the Olympic Peninsula.
  • We inferred that fluid pressure propagates from within the slab to the plate interface, and then updip along the plate interface on times scales associated with the ETS recurrence times (3 to 6 months).
  • Along-strike variations in lithology of the overlying crust correspond to along-strike variations in slow slip occurrence updip of tremor.
  • We compare tremor and time‐dependent slip inversions of the large 2010 and 2012 ETS events in northern Cascadia.
  • During the along‐strike propagation of the events, peak tremor rates occur up to 25 km ahead of the peak slip rate.
  • Ongoing aseismic slip persists several days after the main tremor front has passed over a given portion of the fault.
  • These observations raise an important question: what process(es) may be acting to promote tremor generation at the start of slip with relatively less tremor during the highest slip rates.
  • We analyzed the effect on in-slab seismicity of over 50 deep ETS events occurring in the Nankai subduction over 17 years.
  • Changes in seismicity rate, size distributions, and stress orientations are temporally associated with the slow slip episodes.

In light of the points listed above, which are summarized from 5 published research papers and numerous national and international conference presentations, we have advanced understanding of the relationship between tremor and slow slip and the effect of tidal and other stress changes on tremor generation.

 


Last Modified: 07/17/2022
Modified by: Heidi Houston
por.por_txt_cntn:
Broadly stated, the general goals of this research were to characterize the behavior and mechanics of slow slip regions that are located downdip of locked subduction zone megathrusts. This is of interest because these slow slip regions gradually transfer stress to the locked seismogenic zone and thereby play a key role in loading the locked zone. More specifically, we aimed to study slow slip using seismic tremor occurring mainly in the Cascadia subduction zone, but also in the Nankai, Japan subduction zone. Tremor and slow slip occur together and propagate alomng strike through portions of the Cascadia and Nankai subduction zones, marking the occurrence of large but very slow earthquakes. This phenomenon occurs repeated and rather regularly and is termed Episodic Tremor and Slip (ETS).

One particular approach that we utilized involves analyzing how tremor is triggered by tidal or other stress changes. These stress changes can serve as calibrated probes of the stress state of the tremorgenic portion of the slow slip zone. Other approaches that we pursued included analyzing large slow slip events using GPS data, with a focus on spatial and temporal comparisons between tremor and slow slip.

Data analysis was performed using tremor and low frequency earthquake (LFE) catalogs, tidal stresses, GPS data, and earthquake catalogs. We made comparisons of stress characteristics with tremor occurrence. We estimated the distribution of slip from GPS data. In addition, we analyzed temporal relationships between seismicity in the subducting slab and about 50 ETSs beneath the Kii Peninsula on the Nankai subduction zone.

The research objectives were to determine in detail:

1 - the relationship between tidal stress and tremor or LFEs (Houston, 2015; Sweet et al., 2019)

2 - the spatial distribution of slow slip in large ETSs and relation to tremor from GPS (Hall et al., 2018)

3 - the spatiotemporal relationships between propagating slow slip and tremor (Hall et al., 2019) 

4 - the characteristics of deep in-slab seismicity that may be affected by tremor and slow slip earthquakes in the Kii Peninsula portion of the Nankai subduction zone Japan (Kita et al, 2021).

Significant results from the research that was supported by this grant (EAR 1447005/1911629) include the following:

The sensitivity of tremor to tidal stress rises during large slow slip events (ETSs) in Cascadia, and grows for several days as slip on the fault accumulates.
The functional form of the relationship between tidal stress and tremor was determined, and will provide constraints on models of the slow slip process.
The relationship between tidal stress and tremor allowed me to calculate a coefficient of intrinsic friction for the deep fault, and this showed that the deep fault material is intrinsically very weak.


Absolute locations of these LFE families place them very near and probably on the inferred Juan de Fuca-North America plate interface.
The LFE families respond to tidal stress in a manner similar to tremor, but with these data we can now detect that the sensitivity to tidal stress increases with downdip position.
Over several days of slow slip at an LFE patch during large ETSs, LFEs become increasingly correlated with positive tidal stressing.
Observed LFE behavior provides evidence for stress transfer and increased frictional strength with position updip through the tremor zone.
We present slip distributions for a catalog of six major ETS events from 2007 to 2016.


Slow slip is mostly co-located with tremor, but also extends about 15 km updip of tremor beneath the Olympic Peninsula.
We inferred that fluid pressure propagates from within the slab to the plate interface, and then updip along the plate interface on times scales associated with the ETS recurrence times (3 to 6 months).


Along-strike variations in lithology of the overlying crust correspond to along-strike variations in slow slip occurrence updip of tremor.
We compare tremor and time‐dependent slip inversions of the large 2010 and 2012 ETS events in northern Cascadia.
During the along‐strike propagation of the events, peak tremor rates occur up to 25 km ahead of the peak slip rate.
Ongoing aseismic slip persists several days after the main tremor front has passed over a given portion of the fault.
These observations raise an important question: what process(es) may be acting to promote tremor generation at the start of slip with relatively less tremor during the highest slip rates.
We analyzed the effect on in-slab seismicity of over 50 deep ETS events occurring in the Nankai subduction over 17 years.
Changes in seismicity rate, size distributions, and stress orientations are temporally associated with the slow slip episodes.


In light of the points listed above, which are summarized from 5 published research papers and numerous national and international conference presentations, we have advanced understanding of the relationship between tremor and slow slip and the effect of tidal and other stress changes on tremor generation.
